results.title: Go to jail (A)
results.creator_credit: Lin Buckfield and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
This program discusses the impacts of decisions by the Northern Territory and Western Australian governments to introduce mandatory sentencing for juveniles. The laws have caused a storm of protest from civil rights advocates who view mandatory sentencing as an attack on young Aboriginals, who make up over 70 percent of people charged with offences in the Northern Territory. The fact that trivial and first offenders are punished by jail terms is the main driver of discontent. Acknowledgement is made that mandatory sentencing does not work, that there is a high amount of recidivism and that it can be the cause of deaths in custody. Includes interviews with members of the Aboriginal communities, magistrates, prison officers and Hazel Lallara, the grandmother of a 15 year-old who hanged himself whilst in custody. Reporter: Liz Jackson.

results.title: Vivisection and the alternatives
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”
Experiments for medicine, defence and commerce are shown briefly and the regulations and control of vivisection, in the various states, are mentioned. The alternative - cell, tissue and organ cultures from humans - is shown to be more accurate in some cases. Throughout the film, opinions on the morality and the necessity of vivisection are given.

results.title: The Shame (A)
results.creator_credit: Virginia Moncrieff and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
This program discusses domestic violence and sexual abuse in the Aboriginal communities in regional and outback Australia, where Aboriginal women are fifteen times more likely to be hospitalised and ten times more likely to die from domestic assaults than their white counterparts. There is also a frighteningly high rate of sexual abuse of young Aboriginal children and as Patrick Dodson (Chairman, Reconciliation Council 1991-97) quite poignantly remarks “At stake is the survival of Aboriginal people”. Rather than laying blame, reporter Liz Jackson attempts to find out why domestic abuse is so prevalent and what, if anything, is being done to improve conditions for the Aboriginal communities. Unemployment, alcohol abuse, boredom, low self-esteem, and cultural rituals contribute, it would appear, to the Aboriginal male aggression towards their family, and particularly their wives. Through interviews and personal stories, “The Shame” provides an insight into this most disturbing and tragic situation which exists among the indigenous people of Australia.

results.title: Moulding with a three-part flask
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Foundry Practice”.
Use of a deep follow board, techniques of facing, ramming and venting a deep green sand core; how to use a check in a three-part flask; and the purpose and method of step-gating

results.title: Preparing a cupola for charging

Episode of Series “Foundry Practice”.

results.title: Moulding on a jolt roll-over pattern drawn machine
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Foundry Practice”.
Explains the principles of the jolt roll-over pattern draw machine; how to fill the drag and jolt it; how to draw the pattern; set the drag and cop pattern plates; fill the cope and jolt it; and finish and close the mould.

results.title: Lost in a crowd
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forty Minutes”.
In this essay on loneliness, five characters in search of someone are sitting on a train. The film shows how each has unsuccessfully tried to remedy their situation. All five share a common problem yet as the train goes down the line not a word is spoken.
